name: Kepler-172
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-172 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-172 is a star with 1.0670000000000002 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.08 times its radius. It is located 2767.63 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-172 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-172 b

Kepler-172 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.94 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-172.

The mass of Kepler-172 b is 7.51 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-172 b is 2.35 that of Earth. At 7.51 Earth masses, Kepler-172 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-172 c

Kepler-172 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.39 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-172.

The mass of Kepler-172 c is 11.96 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-172 c is 2.86 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-172 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-172 d

Kepler-172 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 14.63 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-172.

The mass of Kepler-172 d is 6.76 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-172 d is 2.25 that of Earth. At 6.76 Earth masses, Kepler-172 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-172 e

Kepler-172 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.21 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 35.12 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-172.

The mass of Kepler-172 e is 10.98 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-172 e is 2.76 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-172 e is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-172, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
